results.title: Smash palace
results.creator_credit: Roger Donaldson, New Zealand Film Commission and Aardvark Films
results.brief_description: Smash Palace is a remarkable drama about a marital breakup which erupts into an impulsive kidnapping of a child by the father, and a totally credible escalation to the brink of tragedy. Bruno Lawrence and Anna Jemison play the estranged couple in strong performances. Filmed amongst a vast junk-yard of cars, Donaldson’s direction is economical and enthralling, capturing the tension that goes beneath the surface of this all too real drama.

results.title: In country
results.creator_credit: Norman Jewison, Richard Roth and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: At seventeen, Samantha Hughes of Hopewell, Kentucky is pretty, energetic, headstrong and curious; curious about the father she never knew, and curious about the war that took him away - the war nobody wants to remember. Bruce Willis plays a reclusive vet in this story of a family’s struggle to heal the wounds of Vietnam. This film captures both the horror of battle and the disillusionment of a young soldier who thought war meant glory. Norman Jewison directs this heartfelt and powerful movie highlighted by one of the most poignant final scenes ever filmed - the family’s emotionally stirring, almost wordless visit to the Vietnam Veteran’s Memorial in Washington D.C. “In country” is the term American GI’s used for their time in Vietnam. Based on the novel by Bobbie Ann Mason.

results.title: Figures in a landscape
results.creator_credit: Joseph Losey, John Kohn and Cinecrest
results.brief_description: A helicopter, hovering, swoops, wheels and searches like some malignant mechanical bat. Below two men, their hands tied behind their backs, flee for their lives. MacConnachie, played by Robert Shaw, is forty and Ansell, played by Malcolm McDowell, is in his early twenties. Ahead lies 400 miles of hostile terrain they must cross to escape. Between each other lies a deep mutual mistrust, but they are bound by a common need to escape and survive. MacConnachie moves by instinct and Ansell by reason. On and on the two men are hunted by the unrelenting helicopter, and unlike ordinary men who would keep running, they hunt back.

results.title: Born on the fourth of July
results.creator_credit: Oliver Stone, A. Kitman Ho and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Moving away from the simplified morality and broad sweep of his earlier ‘Platoon’ (1986), Stone’s second film on the Vietnam war, based on the 1976 autobiography of Vietnam veteran Ron Kovac, traces two decades in his life. Beginning when Kovac (Tom Cruise) is a zealous teen who eagerly volunteers for the chance to ‘kill commies’, the narrative focuses on his experiences after he is wounded in Vietnam resulting in paralysis from the waist down. Undergoing a slow painful rehabilitation in an underfunded and unsympathetic veteran’s hospital back in the US, he gradually develops a political consciousness and begins to participate in the anti-war movement. An impassioned, compelling film, which is at times, overbearing and bombastic in its exploration of patriotism. Cast also includes Raymond J. Barry, Caroline Kava, Kyra Sedgwick, Brian Larkin, Willem Dafoe, and Lili Taylor.

results.title: Biloxi blues
results.creator_credit: Mike Nichols, Ray Stark and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: The year is 1943 and Eugene Morris Jerome, (Matthew Broderick), finds himself far from the comforts of his Brooklyn home when he is drafted and sent to basic training in Mississippi. Expecting to find donuts and USO dances, he instead encounters a weird and sadistic drill sergeant, (Christopher Walken), and a platoon of often hostile recruits. Armed only with his sense of humour and a quick wit, Eugene is determined to survive the rigours of army life and leave the camp with everything he came with… except his virginity. Directed by Mike Nichols, Neil Simon’s hilarious adaptation of his long-running Broadway comedy is the story of Eugene’s comical travels from adolescence to adulthood.

results.title: Casualties of war
results.creator_credit: Brian De Palma, Art Linson and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Hailed by critics as a masterpice, this film is based on the true story of a squad of U.S. soldiers caught in the moral dilemma of wartime Vietnam. Witness to a vile crime, Private Ericksson (Michael J. Fox) is forced to stand alone against his fellow soldiers and commanding officer Sergeant Meserve (Sean Penn), a powerful and charismatic man pushed over the edge of barbarism by the terror and brutality of combat. With sweeping scope, action and raw power, master filmmaker, Brian De Palma creates a devastating and unforgettable tale of one man’s quest for sanity and justice amidst the chaos of war. Based upon the book by Daniel Lang.

results.title: Almost an Angel
results.creator_credit: John Cornell, Ironbark Films and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Australian funnyman Paul Hogan stars as a thief who’s convinced he’s an angel. Hogan is career criminal Terry Dean, who’s hit by a car while saving the life of a little girl. When Terry regains consciousness, he awakens in a place strangely like heaven, with a God who looks strangely like Charlton Heston! Terry emerges from this vision believing he’s an angel - a belief that propels him and those he encounters into some howlingly funny and heartfelt predicaments.

constellations_other.name: Divining the divine
constellations_other.description: Depicting the Almighty in paintings was frowned upon in the early 1800s in Britain, much like it has been throughout the history of cinema, according to writer Scot Hughes, who made many of these connections in a 2003 article in the Sydney Morning Herald.

results.title: The Odd Angry Shot
results.creator_credit: Tom Jeffrey, Sue Milliken and Samson Productions
results.brief_description: John Jarratt plays a young man who enlists to serve in Vietnam. The film follows him as he serves active duty in one of the toughest of army units - the Australian Special Air Service. In between the savagery of combat the men of the unit gamble, play tricks on each other and drink a numbing amount of alcohol. This hard-edged comedy is a celebration of the Australian male ethos of larrikinism. Amid both the horror and tedium of war, it is only the mens’ sense of humour that saves them from descending into madness. One of the few Australian features to deal directly with Australian combat in Vietnam, “The Odd Angry Shot” features an excellent cast including John Hargreaves, Bryan Brown, Graeme Blundell and Graham Kennedy. Based on the novel by William Nagle.

results.title: The Last Metro = Le Derniere Metro
results.creator_credit: Francois Truffaut, SFP, S A -TF1, SEDIF and Les Films Carrosse
results.brief_description: It is Paris, 1942, under the German Occupation, and successful Jewish theatrical director, Lucas Steiner, is forced into hiding. He entrusts the running of the theatre to his wife Marion, who must contend with Daxiat, a pro-Nazi critic. Masterful direction by Truffaut captures the climate of the occupation.

results.title: Whatever happened to Baby Jane?
results.creator_credit: Robert Aldrich and Seven Arts Productions
results.brief_description: Bette Davis plays Jane Hudson, an aging alcoholic whose vauderville career as child-star “Baby Jane” has faded to obscurity. Her sister Blanche (Jane Crawford) lived in Jane’s shadow as a girl but enjoyed a successful adult career as a glamourous film star until an “accident” left her wheelchair-bound. The aging sisters live alone in a gloomy Hollywood mansion, with Jane becoming increasingly eccentric and keeping Blanche a virtual prisoner. After a series of horrific incidents, the obsessive relationship between the two draws to a sinister conclusion. Based on the novel by Henry Farrell.
